So here's what's up. I'm not trying to slam Clinton, but frankly, he only cared about the prime minister of his pants. I walk around this area, and all I see is a bunch of people whining about what's in it for them, and somehow saying that all the consequences of everything bad is somehow because Bush lied about weapons of mass destruction, and I hate it when people would rather whine than do anything constructive. That's why I enlisted. No sense trying to convince anybody that peace can only be reached when order is established. I have always thought of peace as a goal, and sometimes war is the path to that objective. Sometimes a person like Saddam has to be removed from the equation to get the solution. Sometimes the Taliban or Al Qaeda need to be crushed to be at peace. But nobody here agrees, so I enlisted so that I could speak out loud without having things thrown at me by the very people who want to accept everyone. How can somebody be "liberal" and "accepting" and "tolerant" and get so angry and offended about a worldview other than their own? Sounds more liberating to accept that there is a right and wrong, that relativity is an excuse and not a reason, and do the right thing. I don't care if everybody does the right thing, but I believe "the right thing" exists, and that "liberates" me to do it. I thought I should publish this as a post, rather than a comment, so that it will be easy for everyone to find. That way everyone gets a chance to react and comment, and I like when I get comments.

What the world is lacking in most is people who are willing to sacrifice themselve, their wants and desires and dreams, to serve others. There aren't enough people willing to be like a good dog. There aren't enough people willing to die for something larger than themselves. People are too concerned with their rights, their benefits, their annual bonus or vacation time or privacy. Privacy? The more you need privacy, the more your privacy needs to be invaded! If you aren't doing something wrong, privacy isn't necessary! Shame is what inspires this. And if you are more concerned with others than yourself, you won't be ashamed. Not that I feel like everybody needs to be watched all the time, but it is good to be aware of each other. Back to being aware of others, rather than just aware of what we want for ourselves. "For even the Son of Man did not come to be served, but to serve, and to give His life as a ransom for many." There is a hero, a man Who can be looked up to as watching out for others. Big brother didn't have to watch Him, and he didn't bug everybody about His rights, even when He was being executed. He made sure that His mom and His friends had the things that they needed to survive, to thrive, to establish a worldwide church, and He gave Himself completely to saving the world instead of Himself. Little Melissa comes home from first grade and tells her father that they learned about the history of Valentine's Day. "Since Valentine's Day is for a Christian saint and we're Jewish," she asks, "will God get mad at me for giving someone a valentine?" Melissa's father thinks a bit, then says "No, I don't think God would get mad. Who do you want to give a valentine to?" "Osama Bin Laden," she says. "Why Osama Bin Laden?" her father asks, in shock. "Well," she says, "I thought that if a little American Jewish girl could have enough love to give Osama a valentine, he might start to think that maybe we're not all bad, and maybe start loving people a little." "And if other kids saw what I did and sent valentines to Osama, he'd love everyone a lot. And then he'd start going all over the place to tell everyone how much he loved them and how he didn't hate anyone anymore." Her father's heart swells with pride and he looks at his daughter with new found pride. "Melissa, that's the most wonderful thing I've ever heard!"

So anyway, today David decided that the man his wife was given to would just have to deal with it. As in, when Saul first decided to kill David, he took his daughter back and gave her to another man, but now that David is king, he's like, " Nah. I don't think it's cool that you married my wife, so she's gonna be mine again." Hand her over to my servants and go home and cry about it. And he did, because that's what good people do. They give the king's wife back. Is there a parallel here? I hope not, because David's first wife had another husband for a long time while he was off at war. But it answers my other question a little better. My buddy and his wife were asking me about moving on and remarriage and heaps of other crap that I objectively despise , but subjectively desire . The last of which being that if my ex were to be remarried and redivorced, would I still be willing to work things out? This is still a hard one, because now we have David who is married to a widow AND a woman who has been married to another man (both after and before being married to David) , and he will later kill a woman's husband over an adulterous affair and a bastard in the belly. Then there is Hosea, who married a woman who became a whore, and he went and rounded her up to demonstrate forgiveness. I've always wanted to do that. I think that would make him a hero. Unclean, but a hero and a fine example of how to rise above the standard. I would follow the examples of either of these - with a few exceptions surrounding the adultery and murder - but there is also the question of the Law. Granted, it is Levitical and is directed toward a specific level of holiness, but why not aspire to holiness? "Be Holy, as I am Holy," right? And so here is the only verse that I have ever found that I thought resleased me from my covenant: If your wife marries another man and is divorced again, do not take her back. Is that land not much polluted? (if you think about it, there's only so many times you can plow a field that someone else has planted weeds in. Those things are tough to get rid of.) Why choose to take on someone else's chores? Why take over a project another man has chosen to forfeit? Because I am Jesse, and I don't have to be selfish. I don't have to act like I am too good to keep my commitments, to accept that somebody has made mistakes. I mean, I make mistakes pretty consistently, but I would hope for forgiveness if I asked for it, which I do.

I forgot to mention a small detail that could undo everything I said about David and all the smote raiders. That detail being that the person who tried to kill him on a daily basis was pretty much under his protection. He would not allow anybody to kill King Saul on the basis that he was the king, even though he wanted to slaughter David. However, that was a personal dispute, and the raiders were not a threat to him, but his wives. So does this create a contradiction, or a set of rules to live by? Let's apply this to the New Testament. Jesus would let His enemies kill Him, but would defend those He loved. Not necessarily with violence, but with diplomacy and brilliant teachings, inspired by the Holy Spirit. Fine. Let them kill me, but not my family. That is a Hero.

So I finished up I Samuel on the bus today, and I was amused by the input I got from it. Specifically, that David's wives were stolen by raiders. And did he get over it and move on like a good soldier would? That's what we'd hope for, right? Let people do what they are going to do because they have free will and there's nothing you can do about it, right? Nope. He took an army and put an end to their free will with a battle that lasted from dusk the first day into the next night. The way it's worded, they said nobody lived (except for 200 who fled on camels. How many people would have to die to make the 200 survivors look like nobody?) Anyway, my hero got both his wives back and in my opinion, was pretty nice about it. All he did is kill them. That's far more humane than any of my recent thoughts.

I just got a call from my roommate, encouraging me to seek the Lord, not necessarily concerning my wife, but concerning His Presence, to dwell in the presence of God, and let Him work things out in His own way, which is usually beyond our comprehension. I find a lot of people with no faith, or little faith in God. A lot of people believe in God, but think He basically observes the things we do and sometimes gets disappointed and occasionally smiles and blesses us. But those people wouldn't dare to venture out and say God could do anything that they couldn't do. I believe that my abilities are limited, but I have seen evidence that God's abilities are not. I believe He will bless me abundantly, and I believe that that will happen IN THIS LIFE! A great many people assume that because we must struggle sometimes, that means we will not have those things which God has offered to bless us with until we reach the Kingdom of Heaven. Seldom is this true, unless that is all we strive to acheive! We must seek Him, and He will find us when we do. Whether my relationship with God has anything to do with my relationship with Christi has been a subject of long, tiresome debate, which I have been on both sides of many times, but one's relationship with God is understandably reflected in their dealings with people.

After months of neglecting the things I need to do, it's about time I do them. Not because I want to impress anybody with my holiness or anything, but because my soul needs it. I need to be accountable, and I have avoided it for one reason or another since I got back. When I first graduated Basic Training and AIT, I was doing great, and I knew I could deploy at any time. My unit had left for Texas shorthanded and I figured they'd send me as backup, so I spent most of my time with friends and family. After a few months had passed, I was gradually slipping back into my old addictive patterns, slowly enough that it didn't alarm me, but quickly enough that I didn't turn back. Once I knew that I needed help, I was too ashamed to seek it. I didn't want to be accountable for my actions when my actions were inappropriate. My friends want me around, and I would rather be alone in my shame. That time has passed. Now is the time for war.
